doc.ContractDescription: WE WILL ESTIMATE THE AIR-SEA FLUXES OF LATENT HEAT, SENSIBLE HEAT, AND MOMENTUM, AS WELL AS MEASURE OCEAN SURFACE AND SUBSURFACE TEMPERATURE, SALINITY AND VELOCITY IN SUPPORT OF THE SPURS-2 OCEAN SALINITY FIELD CAMPAIGN. THE PRIMARY GOAL WILL BE ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF TERMS IN THE EQUATION GOVERNING THE EVOLUTION OF UPPER-OCEAN SALINITY, LEADING TO IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF PROCESSES AFFECTING BOTH THE LARGE-SCALE SALINITY FIELD AND THE SHALLOW, HIGH-FREQUENCY VARIATIONS IN SURFACE SALINITY. THE LARGER GOAL IS DIAGNOSING THE FACTORS CONTROLLING THE FRESH POOL OF THE NORTHEASTERN TROPICAL PACIFIC. MEASUREMENTS WILL BE OBTAINED BY DEPLOYMENT OF TWO OCEANOGRAPHIC SURFACE MOORINGS ON 125W NEAR 9N AND 10N FOR ONE YEAR, NEAR THE LOCATION OF MAXIMUM PRECIPITATION IN THE PACIFIC INTER-TROPICAL CONVERGENCE ZONE (ITCZ). INVESTIGATORS FROM THE WOODS HOLE OCEANOGRAPHIC INSTITUTION (WHOI) WILL DEPLOY A HEAVILY INSTRUMENTED MOORING AND BUOY AT 10N, 125W. THE BUOY WILL CARRY STATE-OF-THE-ART INSTRUMENTS FOR MEASURING SURFACE METEOROLOGY, INCIDENT SOLAR AND INFRARED RADIATION, AND SUBSURFACE TEMPERATURE, SALINITY, AND VELOCITY, WITH SPECIFIC FOCUS ON MAKING ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF THE SURFACE FRESHWATER FLUXES (EVAPORATION AND PRECIPITATION) AND THE SUBSURFACE HORIZONTAL TRANSPORT OF SALT. THE SURFACE LATENT HEAT, SENSIBLE HEAT, AND MOMENTUM FLUXES WILL BE ESTIMATED USING BULK FORMULAS THAT RELATE THE TURBULENT FLUXES IN TERMS OF MORE EASILY MEASURED MEAN VARIABLES (E.G., 1-HR AVERAGE HUMIDITY, TEMPERATURE AND WIND SPEED) THROUGH TRANSFER COEFFICIENTS. ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF THE EVAPORATION RATE, PROPORTIONAL TO THE SURFACE LATENT HEAT FLUX, ARE OF PARTICULAR IMPORTANCE TO THIS PROGRAM. THE WHOI MOORING WILL ALSO CARRY ATMOSPHERIC TURBULENCE INSTRUMENTS TO MAKE DIRECT MEASUREMENTS OF THE SURFACE MOMENTUM FLUX AND LATENT AND SENSIBLE HEAT FLUXES. IN ADDITION TO INSTRUMENTS FOR ACCURATE QUANTIFICATION OF AIR-SEA FLUXES, THE MOORING AND BUOY WILL ALSO CARRY A FULL COMPLEMENT OF OTHER INSTRUMENTS THAT WILL ALLOW INSIGHT INTO THE DYNAMICS AND PROCESSES AFFECTING SURFACE AND SUBSURFACE SALINITY, INCLUDING: DENSELY SPACED (2 M) MEASUREMENTS OF T AND S NEAR THE SURFACE WITH TEMPORAL RESOLUTION OF MINUTES, VERTICAL PROFILES OF T, S, AND VELOCITY SPANNING THE UPPER 1500 M (WITH HIGHER RESOLUTION ABOVE 200 M), SURFACE-WAVE MEASUREMENTS, AND A SPECIAL FOCUS ON PRECIPITATION MEASUREMENTS. A PACIFIC MARINE ENVIRONMENTAL LABORATORY (PMEL) PRAWLER PROFILING MOORING AND SURFACE BUOY AT 9N, 125W WILL MEASURE NEARLY CONTINUOUS VERTICAL PROFILES OF TEMPERATURE AND SALINITY FROM 10-500 M AND WILL CARRY A SURFACE METEOROLOGY PACKAGE TO MEASURE PRECIPITATION, WIND, AIR TEMPERATURE, HUMIDITY, AND BAROMETRIC PRESSURE. THE PMEL MOORING WILL ALSO MEASURE SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURE AND SALINITY. THIS PROJECT FEATURES A SPECIAL FOCUS ON PRECIPITATION. THE PMEL AND WHOI MOORINGS WILL CARRY MULTIPLE INSTRUMENTS FOR MEASURING PRECIPITATION, INCLUDING CONVENTIONAL RAIN GAUGES AND SUBSURFACE HYDROPHONES THAT WILL BE PREPARED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTONS APPLIED PHYSICS LABORATORY (APL-UW). IN ADDITION, OUR TEAM INCLUDES ATMOSPHERIC SCIENTISTS WHO WILL WORK TO INTERPRET THE IN SITU AND SATELLITE MEASUREMENTS OF RAINFALL AND CLOUD PROPERTIES AND PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO THE LARGER SPURS-2 GROUP ON THE SPATIO-TEMPORAL SCALES OF THE PRECIPITATING SYSTEMS AND THE BROADER SYNOPTIC WEATHER CONTEXT.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF PHASE VII B GLOVE SYSTEM

SAO WILL SUPPORT THE NASA JWST PROJECT OFFICE BY PROVIDING SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTISE DURING MEETINGS AND PERFORMING TASKS DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE JWST AND ITS SUBSYSTEMS, IN PARTICULAR THE OPTICAL TELESCOPE ELEMENT OTE. THESE TASKS WILL INCLUDE ADVISING THE GOVERNMENT ON THE PERFORMANCE OF THE OTE DESIGN, THE OTE MODELING EFFORT, THE INTEGRATION AND TEST VIBRATION, ACOUSTIC, CRYOGENIC AND OPTICAL FOR EACH PMSA, THE SMA, THE AOS, THE PATHFINDER OGSE 1,2 AND THE PMBSS. THE SAO TEAM WILL CONTINUE TO REVIEW THE PMBSS AS ITS DESIGN AND ASSEMBLY ENTERS ITS FINAL STAGES. DEVELOP HIGHLY SPECIALIZED MODELS AS NECESSARY TO VALIDATE LOCALIZED KEY DESIGN FEATURE AND OR WHERE ASSEMBLY HAS NOT BEEN ACCOMPLISHED TO PRINT. CONTINUE TO REVIEW STATIC TEST PLANS FOR THE PMBSS WINGS&CS BS. DEVELOP AND INTEGRATE HIGHLY SPECIALIZED MODELS TO VERIFY THAT THE PMBSS WINGS&CS BSF ARE BEING TESTED TO 1.25 DLL. CONTINUE TO DEVELOP PLANS FOR PATHFINDER OGSE 1, 2 ADJUNCT OPTICAL METROLOGY. CONTINUE TO REVIEW TEST PLANS FOR ALL OPTICAL, CRYOGENIC, VIBRATION ACOUSTIC AND STRENGTH TESTS. USING OUR HIGHLY SPECIALIZED INDEPENDENT MODELS, VERIFY THE OTE&OBS TEST OBJECTIVES WILL BE MET. CONTINUE TO PREPARE OPTICAL AND STRESS BASED PREDICTIONS FOR ALL OF THE ABOVE TESTS USING SAOS INDEPENDENTLY CREATED FEMS USING GFE CFE THERMAL DATA, CREATE IN SITU PREDICTIONS FOR ALL OTE CRYOGENIC TESTS AND COMPARE TO TEST DATA. PROVIDE HIGHLY SPECIALIZED THERMAL MODELS AND PREDICTIONS FOR THE PATHFINDER OGSE 1,2 NASA JSC TESTS. INTEGRATE SAO DERIVED MODELS WITH NASA JSC CHAMBER MODELS AND OTHER GSE MODELS TO PROVIDE A SINGLE, HIGHLY SPECIALIZED AND UNIQUE TEST MODE. PERFORM PATHFINDER THERMAL DISTORTION ANALYSIS USING OUR INDEPENDENT DEVELOPED HIGHLY SPECIALIZED FEMS. CONTINUE TO DOCUMENT ALL ACTIVITIES AND COMMUNICATE WITH THE GSFC JWST PROJECT PERSONNEL VIA ON SITE MEETINGS, TELEPHONE CONFERENCES, DETAILED TECHNICAL MEMOS&EMAILS.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE A THOROUGH INVESTIGATION INTO THE NET RADIATIVE FORCINGS FROM FOREST FIRES IN THE ABOVE DOMAIN. FIRE IS THE DOMINANT DISTURBANCE IN BOREAL NORTH AMERICA AND STRONGLY REGULATES ECOSYSTEM COMPOSITION AND LAND-ATMOSPHERE EXCHANGES OF CARBON, WATER, AND ENERGY. MULTIPLE LINES OF EVIDENCE POINT TO AN INTENSIFICATION OF THE FIRE REGIME DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE; THESE DISTURBANCES, IN TURN, INFLUENCE CLIMATE THROUGH MULTIPLE AND OFTEN COUNTERACTING PATHWAYS. FOR EXAMPLE, FIRES THAT COMBUST LARGE AMOUNTS OF ORGANIC MATTER AND DEPOSIT BLACK CARBON ON ICE AND SNOW WILL WARM THE CLIMATE, WHEREAS FIRES THAT DRAMATICALLY INCREASE SPRING ALBEDO BY EXPOSING MORE UNDERLYING SNOW WILL LEAD TO COOLING. THE VULNERABILITY AND RESILIENCE OF OTHER BOREAL AND ARCTIC SYSTEMS, INCLUDING PERMAFROST AND SEA ICE, DEPENDS IN PART ON HOW FIRE REGIMES INTERACT WITH CLIMATE. UNLIKE OTHER LARGE EARTH SYSTEM FEEDBACKS, WE HAVE SOME DIRECT LEVEL OF CONTROL OVER FIRE REGIMES. FEDERAL AND STATE/PROVINCIAL AGENCIES IN ALASKA AND CANADA INVEST CONSIDERABLE RESOURCES INTO CONTROLLING FIRES FOR MULTIPLE PURPOSES. THE WARMING OR COOLING POTENTIAL FROM FIRES, HOWEVER, IS CURRENTLY NOT TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT. WE BELIEVE THIS REPRESENTS A SIGNIFICANT UNTAPPED CLIMATE MITIGATION SERVICE FROM BOREAL FORESTS. WHILE MANY OF THESE AGENCIES ARE KEENLY INTERESTED, THE INFORMATION NEEDED TO EXPLOIT THIS ECOSYSTEM SERVICE IS ENTIRELY LACKING. THE VALUE OF THIS INFORMATION WILL ONLY INCREASE IN TIME AS CARBON AND CLIMATE FORCINGS BECOME MONETIZED AND MORE TIGHTLY REGULATED. OUR PRIMARY SCIENCE GOAL WILL BE TO DEVELOP MAPS OF FIRE FORCINGS ACROSS THE ABOVE DOMAIN DURING THE 2002 2011 ERA. TO DO SO WE WILL EMPLOY EXISTING AND NEW REMOTE SENSING DATASETS TO QUANTIFY CARBON CONSUMPTION BY WILDFIRE AND LONG-TERM CHANGES TO SPRING ALBEDO (WHICH HAS BEEN SHOWN TO BE THE DOMINANT BIOPHYSICAL FORCING FROM FIRES IN ALASKA AND CANADA). NEW FIELD MEASUREMENTS OF COMBUSTION FROM UNDER-SAMPLED FOREST AND BURNING TYPES WILL ADD CRITICAL CONSTRAINTS TO OUR COMBUSTION MODEL. WE WILL EMPLOY A STATE-OF-THE-ART LAND SURFACE AND EARTH SYSTEM MODEL TO CHARACTERIZE (1) POST-FIRE BIOMASS REGROWTH AS IT IS AFFECTED BY SPATIALLYVARYING DRIVERS, AND (2) FORCINGS FROM CARBONACEOUS AEROSOLS INCLUDING THEIR SUBSEQUENT DEPOSITION ONTO SNOW AND ICE. THESE DATA LAYERS WILL ALLOW US TO NOT ONLY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE CLIMATE IMPACTS FROM FIRES, BUT TO INCLUDE THESE IMPACTS INTO NEW MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORKS. TO FACILITATE THE LATTER, WE WILL DEVELOP A SET OF PREDICTIVE MODELS OF POTENTIAL FIRE FORCINGS THAT EVOLVE OVER THE FIRE SEASON AND CAN BE INTEGRATED INTO CURRENT DECISION-MAKING TOOLS. FUNDAMENTAL TO THIS EFFORT WILL BE CONTINUED BILATERAL COMMUNICATION WITH MANAGERS. WE WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH STAKEHOLDERS FROM VARIOUS AGENCIES IN ALASKA AND CANADA TO UNDERSTAND THEIR NEEDS AND RELAY THE IMPORTANCE AND PRACTICALITY OF OUR RESEARCH. RESULTS FROM THIS FIRST PHASE WILL FORM THE FOUNDATION FOR FURTHER DEVELOPMENT IN PHASE II OF ABOVE, INCLUDING FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF FIRE FEEDBACKS AND THE DEVELOPMENT AND REFINEMENT OF OPERATIONAL FIRE MANAGEMENT TOOLS. WE HAVE ASSEMBLED AN INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM THAT INCLUDES EXTENSIVE EXPERTISE IN FIRE-RELATED FIELD MEASUREMENTS, OPTICAL AND INFRARED REMOTE SENSING, STATISTICAL COMBUSTION MODELING, EARTH SYSTEM MODELING, AND FIRE MANAGEMENT. WE AIM TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATE-DISTURBANCE INTERACTIONS IN THE ABOVE DOMAIN, BUT PERHAPS MORE IMPORTANTLY DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR UTILIZING THE CLIMATE MITIGATION SERVICE THAT FIRES EITHER CREATE OR DEGRADE. A HOLISTIC UNDERSTANDING OF FIRE-RELATED ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IS CRITICAL FOR THE INCREASINGLY COMPLEX MANAGEMENT OF NORTHERN FORESTS AND THE SOCIETAL BENEFITS THEY PROVIDE.

doc.ContractDescription: THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO TEST THE GIANT-IMPACT HYPOTHESIS AS THE PRIMARY MOON-FORMING EVENT AND SUBSEQUENT FORMATION OF THE MOON ITSELF IN THE PROTO-LUNAR SILICATE VAPOR DISK GENERATED BY THIS IMPACT. TO ACHIEVE THIS OBJECTIVE WE PROPOSE TO MEASURE (1) K ISOTOPIC COMPOSITIONS OF LUNAR SAMPLES, METEORITES, AND TERRESTRIAL STANDARDS BY MULTICOLLECTOR ICP-MS, (2) ELEMENTAL CONCENTRATIONS BY QUADRUPOLE ICP-MS, AND (3) TO CARRY OUT MODELING OF THE CHEMICAL AND ISOTOPIC EVOLUTION OF THE PROTO-LUNAR SILICATE VAPOR DISK USING THE UPDATED VERSION OF THE GRAINS. FOR THE K ISOTOPIC MEASUREMENTS WE HAVE ALREADY DEVELOPED A NEW ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUE THAT ALLOWS ACHIEVING AN ACCURACY OF<0.04 PER MIL FOR INDIVIDUAL MEASUREMENTS. FOR MODELING, THE 20-ELEMENT VERSION OF THE GRAINS CODE, ALREADY SUCCESSFULLY USED BY US, WILL BE EXTENDED TO 45 ELEMENTS OF DIFFERENT GEO- AND COSMOCHEMICAL AFFINITIES THAT COVER THE WHOLE RANGE OF DEPLETIONS OF THE BULK MOON RELATIVE TO THE BULK SILICATE EARTH. THE CODE WILL BE ALSO EXTENDED TO INCLUDE MODELING OF EQUILIBRIUM ISOTOPE FRACTIONATIONS OF ALL RELEVANT ELEMENTS FOR WHICH APPROPRIATE FRACTIONATION FACTORS ARE KNOWN OR COULD BE RELIABLY ESTIMATED. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH, WHEN COMPLETED, WILL (1) YIELD A BETTER ESTIMATE OF THE BULK MOON COMPOSITION; (2) ANSWER THE QUESTIONS OF WHETHER THE EARTH-MOON SYSTEM IS DIFFERENT IN K ISOTOPES FROM OTHER DIFFERENTIATED AND UNDIFFERENTIATED BODIES, AND WHETHER THERE IS A DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE EARTH AND THE MOON; AND (3) DETERMINE THE RANGE OF DISK MODELS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH BOTH THE VOLATILE ELEMENT DEPLETIONS AND ISOTOPIC CONSTRAINTS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH FOCUSES ON UNDERSTANDING THE FORMATION AND EARLY EVOLUTION OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM THAT IS THE MAJOR GOAL OF NASA'S EMERGING WORLDS PROGRAM: INCREASE "UNDERSTANDING OF THE FORMATION AND EARLY EVOLUTION OF OUR SOLAR SYSTEM". AS A BONUS, OUR SAMPLE-FOCUSED WORK WILL ALSO HELP TO MAXIMIZE THE IMMEDIATE SIGNIFICANCE OF NEW SAMPLES WHICH EVENTUALLY WILL BE RETURNED FROM THE MOON, MARS, AND ASTEROIDS BY FUTURE NASA SPACE MISSIONS.

TASK ORDER TITLE: ENERGY STAR FACTS AND INDICATORS TRACKING THE PURPOSE OF THIS TASK ORDER IS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PRODUCT, PARTNER, AND/OR PROGRAM-SPECIFIC INITIATIVES EXECUTED IN SUPPORT OF THE ENERGY STAR. SPECIFIC TASKS INCLUDE: NATIONAL ANALYSIS OF THE CONSORTIUM FOR ENERGY EFFICIENCY (CEE) HOUSEHOLD SURVEY DATASET TO ANALYZE THIS DATASET ON A NATIONAL BASIS AND COMPILE A REPORT ON KEY FINDINGS; DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A DETAILED RETAIL STORE LEVEL (RSL) ASSESSMENT THAT ASSESSES THE ACCURACY OF ENERGY STAR QUALIFIED PRODUCT LABELING IN STORES; FOR THE CREATION/COMPILATION, REVIEW, AND DOCUMENTATION OF KEY PROGRAM FACTS AND A COMPILATION OF CONSUMER TIPS TO BE USED TO COMMUNICATE INFORMATION TO THE CONSUMERS, THE MEDIA, AND OTHER INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS ON THE BENEFITS OF ENERGY STAR QUALIFYING PRODUCTS; AND FOR ESTIMATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE ENERGY STAR PRODUCTS PROGRAM IN MEETING ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND RELATED ENVIRONMENTAL GOALS BY USING THE E-CAST PLATFORM WHICH WAS ADAPTED FROM A NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED PLATFORM FOR ESTIMATING ENERGY SAVINGS. THE PURPOSE OF MODIFICATION NO. 4 IS TO MAKE AN ADMINISTRATIVE CORRECTION TO THE TASK ORDER TITLE OF THE SUBJECT ORDER. IGF::OT::IGF
